Dylan Howlett
Son, brother, friend, Tar Heel. Formerly: @NBCOlympics researcher, @SINow intern. Currently: @stoglo23. Always: nearsighted. Email: howlettd.11@gmail.com
Apr 10

Five Years

Learning what it is, exactly, that binds us to a place.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C. — A handful of years started with a leap and ended with one. They both sprang from concrete in the darkness of April. The first led to a place of promise, the fulfillment of which gave uplift to the last.

There was the first April, and the first glimpse of what could be. It came in the early morning hours after an evening alone, another one, in Apartment 212D on the west end of Chicago’s Fullerton Avenue. A laptop screen, bearing news of an accepted transfer application to UNC-Chapel Hill, lit an unsure face. Three months before those eyes, reddened beneath glasses, had pressed up against the screen with beseeching pain. “Mom,” I heaved over Skype. “I don’t know if I can do this.” This being college, the presumed zenith, and this being emptiness, my assumed nadir. I returned the night before after six weeks home, where everything was right. Here, again, was everything that was wrong. The regret was too searing. The seclusion was too much. “Tomorrow,” my mom said. “Just get to tomorrow.”

The problem was today. Today was every day. I wondered how I got here, to DePaul, the nation’s largest Catholic institution, and lost my faith in tomorrow. I wondered why I had to haul myself out of bed with strained conviction that it was all right, that some measure of zen lay beyond my morning cereal and hockey highlights. It did not.

I saw in the faces of others, those who were well-adjusted, that look of centeredness I so loathed. They had friends, and purpose, and fullness. They commuted from Lake View and Belmont and Jefferson Park, parachuting in with readymade social groups and homemade reassurance. I had Sunday nights at Dominick’s, the local grocery store on the corner of Fullerton and Sheffield, where I’d dawdle in front of Granny Smith apples, and dry cereal, and the cold cuts at the deli counter, all to delay my return to Apartment 212D. To my life.

I talked to my parents, separately, every night. My mom Skyped. My dad called. The reports I gave were redundant, and morose. They remained upbeat. It was hard to betray their certainty that it would get better, and even harder to admit that it wasn’t. I knew nobody. I was nobody. On New Year’s Day, two days before my mom’s prescribed tomorrow, I packed my bags and found my dog, Boo, on the corner of our family room couch. I couldn’t say it out loud. I buried my face in his stomach until my dad asked if I was O.K., and I answered with muffled sobs through matted fur. There was no tomorrow.

But it came, as did the next day, and the day after that, and another. I met weekly with older cousins who kept me well fed and sane. I started running again after giving it up during the first quarter, when I felt too impotent to wander any farther for a weekend lunch than the Starbucks beneath my apartment. I burrowed into my coursework. I plotted my escape. The hatch, I figured, rested somewhere in everything this wasn’t.

Dreams grow tired, and hearts grow weary, until a place, and its people, can revive them. I knew this without understanding it. So it was on that April morning, in Apartment 212D, that I read about my acceptance to the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, and felt the weight pour out of my legs.

It is fruitless, many have found, to capture what it means, and how it feels, to be here. Some have inquired outright about what it is, exactly, that binds us to this place as it does. There is no definitive answer. I remember walking around campus for the first time and feeling an unmistakable sense of belonging, of being home, and not having the faintest idea why. That is today in Chapel Hill. That is every day in Chapel Hill.

And so its mysterious ways began to repair all of my freshman year fissures. With Franklin Street outings and residence hall hijinks. With basketball hysteria and dining hall hysterics. With holy sunsets and a divine breeze. But the mystery, I’ve learned, lies only in its benevolent deceit: that it is this place, and this place alone, that could make you feel so. It’s what we’ve been told, and what we’ve long believed. It is not so. That is the final leap.

I took my final leap with seven seconds left in last Monday’s national title game, when Justin Jackson sauntered down the Phoenix court for a runaway jam. It was there, in the back corner of a crowded restaurant and bar, that my legs reached acceptance letter heights. Not because of a basketball championship, or redemption, or any of the various sports-infused contrivances that we convince ourselves will make us feel whole. For completion doesn’t lie somewhere: It lies with someone. With many. I leapt in the bar for them.

I followed the hordes up Henderson Street and onto Franklin, sprinting along the yellow divider in plodding rainboots. I looked for them among the 55,000 people set to converge on that sacred intersection. Soon the minute hand would nudge forward to midnight. To tomorrow.

A gap appeared in the thicket of revelers, and I found them, all three. They had already linked arms in the middle of the street, and I could see them staggering with euphoric disbelief. It was much like the sensation I had, repeatedly, in my three years as a student, when I’d walk along the treelined bricks and wonder how I’d gotten here. I can’t believe I go to this school. That is, again, the benevolent deceit.

It lies in the swaying arm-linked trio, and the scores they represent, the thousands who have come before and will come long after. It is the people here who revive us, and reveal in us the very best, we hope, of ourselves. Those who can take someone so shattered, so uncertain, and put him back together with enough adhesive to span two lifetimes. I will remember, forever, their faces amid the fray near that intersection, where we tilted our heads and offered carnal screams to the heavens. We gave thanks, with wide mouths and wider eyes, to Chapel Hill, for teaching us that one place, and its people, can make you feel so.

I had little choice when I found them. I leapt onto their shoulders.
